Congratulations on noticing improvements in your flexibility from yoga! That's a great motivator to continue your exercise journey.

As for getting back into jogging, I'd be happy to offer some tips to help you ease into it:

1. **Start with walk-jog intervals**: Begin with short jogging intervals (2-3 minutes) followed by walking breaks. Gradually increase the jogging time and reduce the walking intervals as you build up your endurance.
2. **Ease into it**: Don't try to do too much too soon. If you're new to jogging or getting back into it after a break, start with shorter distances (20-30 minutes) and gradually increase your duration and frequency.
3. **Get proper gear**: Invest in a good pair of jogging shoes that provide support and cushioning. Dress comfortably and wear breathable clothing.
4. **Warm up and cool down**: Always warm up with 5-10 minutes of light cardio (jogging in place, jumping jacks, etc.) and stretching before jogging. After your jog, cool down with static stretches to help your body recover.
5. **Create a schedule**: Plan out your jogging routine and stick to it. Start with 2-3 times a week and increase the frequency as your body adapts.
6. **Listen to your body**: Pay attention to your body's signals. If you experience any discomfort, pain, or fatigue, stop and rest. It's better to take a break than to risk injury.
7. **Find a jogging buddy or accountability partner**: Having someone to jog with or report to can help keep you motivated and accountable.
8. **Track your progress**: Use a fitness tracker, app, or log to monitor your progress, pace, and distance. This can help you stay motivated and see the improvements.
9. **Stay hydrated and fueled**: Make sure to drink plenty of water before, during, and after your jog. Also, fuel your body with a balanced diet that includes complex carbohydrates, protein, and healthy fats.
10. **Be patient and consistent**: Getting back into jogging takes time, effort, and patience. Don't get discouraged if you don't see immediate results. Stick to your routine, and you'll eventually see progress.

Remember, it's essential to consult with a healthcare professional before starting any new exercise program, especially if you have any underlying health conditions.

Good luck, and have fun getting back into jogging!
